statement.text: The three major visceral arteries - celiac axis, superior mesenteric artery (SMA), and inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) - supply the gut from stomach to rectum, with extensive collateral networks allowing tolerance of single-vessel occlusion.

explanation.intuition: Three main arteries feed your digestive system: one for the upper part (celiac), one for the middle (SMA), and one for the lower (IMA). They're connected like a network, so if one is blocked, the others can usually pick up the slack.
explanation.key_insight: Single-vessel mesenteric disease is usually asymptomatic due to collateral flow. Symptomatic chronic mesenteric ischemia typically requires occlusion or critical stenosis of at least two of three vessels.
explanation.technical_details: Celiac axis: T12, supplies stomach, liver, spleen, proximal duodenum. SMA: L1, supplies small bowel, right colon to splenic flexure. IMA: L3, supplies left colon, sigmoid, rectum. Collaterals: pancreaticoduodenal arcade (celiac↔SMA), Arc of Riolan (SMA↔IMA), marginal artery of Drummond (along colon). Watershed zones: splenic flexure, rectosigmoid - at risk during low-flow states.

clinical_pearls: Symptomatic chronic mesenteric ischemia requires ≥2 vessel disease
Splenic flexure and rectosigmoid are watershed zones - at risk during hypotension
Arc of Riolan (meandering mesenteric) = IMA-SMA collateral
